sourcing.instructions: Cu: Copper metal from a metallurgical supplier, Ga: Gallium from a chemical supplier, Ni: Nickel metal from a metallurgical supplier, O: Oxygen from atmospheric air, V: Vanadium from a chemical supplier or metallurgical supplier.
steps: Cu: Copper metal from a metallurgical supplier, Ga: Gallium from a chemical supplier, Ni: Nickel metal from a metallurgical supplier, O: Oxygen from atmospheric air, V: Vanadium from a chemical supplier or metallurgical supplier.

1. Weigh 88.55 g of copper (Cu), 13.49 g of gallium (Ga), 53.73 g of nickel (Ni), 48.00 g of oxygen (O) (as part of the compound formation), and 12.00 g of vanadium (V). 2. In a clean, dry mixing container, combine the solid forms of Cu, Ga, Ni, and V. 3. Mix thoroughly with a spatula or mechanical mixer for 10 minutes to ensure a uniform blend. 4. Gradually introduce oxygen (if using as an additive) in a controlled environment to prevent oxidation of the metals.
preparation.raw_text: 1. Weigh 88.55 g of copper (Cu), 13.49 g of gallium (Ga), 53.73 g of nickel (Ni), 48.00 g of oxygen (O) (as part of the compound formation), and 12.00 g of vanadium (V). 2. In a clean, dry mixing container, combine the solid forms of Cu, Ga, Ni, and V. 3. Mix thoroughly with a spatula or mechanical mixer for 10 minutes to ensure a uniform blend. 4. Gradually introduce oxygen (if using as an additive) in a controlled environment to prevent oxidation of the metals.

steps: 1. Preheat a furnace to 1000 °C. 2. Place the mixed powder in a crucible and insert it into the furnace. 3. Heat for 4 hours to ensure proper fusion of the materials.
heating.raw_text: 1. Preheat a furnace to 1000 °C. 2. Place the mixed powder in a crucible and insert it into the furnace. 3. Heat for 4 hours to ensure proper fusion of the materials.

steps: 1. Turn off the furnace and allow it to cool down naturally to room temperature over a period of 6 hours. Do not open the furnace during this time to prevent rapid cooling and cracking.
cooling.raw_text: 1. Turn off the furnace and allow it to cool down naturally to room temperature over a period of 6 hours. Do not open the furnace during this time to prevent rapid cooling and cracking.

steps: 1. Remove the crucible from the furnace once cooled. 2. Carefully extract the solid sample, and inspect for any imperfections. 3. If necessary, sand down any rough edges using fine-grit sandpaper (240 grit) for a smooth finish. 4. Seal the surface with a clear epoxy resin to enhance durability and aesthetic appearance. Allow the epoxy to cure for 24 hours at room temperature.
